pr_title: Issue 5080: Adding character length checks for scope and stream name.

timeline.bodyText:
How does this work with multi-byte unicode character strings?
String#length() counts code units, not code points.
We may want to use String#codePointCount(int, int). This will allow languages in higher unicode planes to also use 255 characters (which can consume up to 4 bytes per character in UTF8 [or two code units in UTF16]).
I believe the limiting factor in a scope name or stream name is the 1MB ZooKeeper ZNode size limit.
Will 255 characters ever be too limiting? 255 characters is like 7 UUIDs.
timeline.author: derekm

replies.bodyText: Some languages use multiple code points for a single character or grapheme. See: http://illegalargumentexception.blogspot.com/2009/05/java-rough-guide-to-character-encoding.html#javaencoding_strnlen
replies.author: derekm

replies.bodyText:
We don't store Stream names in ZK. We stash them inside Table Segment Key-Value Pairs, either as Keys (max 8KB) or values (max 1MB - but may contain more than just a stream name). So the main constraint here will be Key - max 8KB.
Stream names are also part of the Segment names (<Scope-Name>/<Stream-Name>/<Segment-Name>). Given that we use Segment names as FileSystem paths (for NFS) or Object Keys (for S3/ExtS3), and so on, the constraint might be even higher than 8KB.
If you look at the line immediately following this line you'll see a Regex that enforces the name to be alphanumeric. As such, the character count is good enough because ASCII should be enough to encode this. I don't think we should worry about higher-level unicode chars in this case).
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

replies.bodyText:
In case of HDFS, the maximum component length for a file path is 255 bytes in UTF-8 encoding.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HDFS-6055
Since these names are to only contain alphanumeric characters, would using String#codePointCount(int, int) offer any benefits?
replies.author: ldr7

replies.bodyText: If the maximum length for a path is 256, then your change isn't going to fix anything. See my previous comment why.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

replies.bodyText:
@andreipaduroiu

If the maximum length for a path is 256, then your change isn't going to fix anything. See my previous comment why.

I think this means each path part, not the entire path. He is sizing the max length to the limits of HDFS path parts.
@ldr7

Since these names are to only contain alphanumeric characters, would using String#codePointCount(int, int) offer any benefits?

Yeah, my suggestion is invalid given the \p{Alnum} character class constraint. Apologies for the distraction! I can be a stickler about i18n, but I didn't notice it doesn't really apply in this context.
Now the only thing bugging me is we can't throw all constraint violations at once! ;)
